Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for student participation in the Symposium on Undergraduate Research to be held at the Laser Science XXXIII Conference. This conference is of great importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States because almost all work in this area involves lasers in some way. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

The Laser Science XXXIII Conference, which this award supports, is a joint meeting of the American Physical Society's Division of Laser Science and the Optical Society of America's annual meeting to be held in Washington, DC in September 2017. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The seventeenth annual DLS Symposium on Undergraduate Research at LS-XXXIII was held in Washington, DC on Sunday, 17 September, 2017.   This year’s event had a very different schedule from previous years for a number of reasons.  First, the meeting was scheduled for mid-September, a month earlier than usual, and this caused considerable squeezing in the planning and preparation. Second, the symposium was held on a Sunday before the actual FiO/LS meeting officially began.  Third, the sessions were scheduled differently since there was no preceding plenary session as there usually has been.  Needless to say, we were able to adapt to the new schedule with help from the OSA meetings people.


The Symposium has grown from ten presentations in 2001 to forty-nine this year on projects done at about 40 universities or research institutes. There were a few second authors to some submissions, so the total number of participants was 54. This is near the capacity limit for meetings in the present format. These Symposia have brought over 500 students to our annual meetings to present what are often the first research papers of their budding careers.  Programs, articles, further information, and photos from previous symposia can be found at the DLS (APS) website http://www.aps.org/units/dls/meetings/symposium/ and the Stony Brook Laser Teaching Center website at http://laser.physics.sunysb.edu/research-symposium/.

It was gratifying that these very young scientists could give their first presentations at a professional meeting, and it was clearly a memorable event for them. Fifteen of this year's presenters were female, an impressive representation but not as many as we’ve had in previous years.  Many of the students remained at the meeting one or more extra days to hear talks or visit exhibits. Some were thrilled to meet famous and/or highly visible scientists, including the authors of some of their textbooks.  Judging from the enthusiastic notes that accompanied their final expense reports, the student participants will surely remember this opportunity throughout their professional lives.

            This year again we also enjoyed significant corporate support that is detailed below.  In addition there was  a large donation from AIP through SPS, and the dinner from Univ. of Maryland. Also, Thorlabs sent wonderful snack boxes that were enjoyed in the break between sessions. Acknowledgement posters were prominently displayed at all Symposium events.
